# I. The Model
ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’»A Support Vector Machine (SVM) model is a supervisedğŸ‘€ machine learning model used for classification. It is simple but very useful. It uses a toolğŸ”¨ called hyperplane to separate data into different groups. It has different methods for both linear and non-linear data. And the methods that are used here are **svmLinear** and **svmPloy**.    


# II. The Process and Results
Since SVM is a supervised model, the first step is to split the dataset into training and testing sets and assume the dataset is cleanâ™»ï¸. After the dataset split, we runğŸƒ the SVM in the training set and use the trained data to predict the testing set. Finally, we use a ğŸ“ğŸ“confusion matrix to show how well is our prediction in terms of accuracy, recall, Specificity, etc.  
  
We are ğŸ”­interested in the effect of data split ratios on the model performance, so we compare two new ratios, 75:25 and 50:50 with the original ratio of 60:40 conducted by Dr.Hunt. We also implement both linear and poly methods on the dataset to see the difference in their performance.  
  
The result for both splits and poly method are betterğŸ“ˆ than the original model performance, which means that data split does have an impact on the model fitness.  ğŸŠBecause we know that two classes of variables have some overlaps, so it is expected that poly will be a better fit for the dataset. However, we did not test statistical significance for those changesğŸ™Š.

# III. Application
The SVM model can be used for identifying abnormalities such as fraudulent transactions, material misstatements, bankruptcies, abnormal reserves, etc. Auditors can utilize this machine learning model with other algorithms as well as financial ratios to improve their accuracy and efficiency. 

# IV. Code

## i. Data Split 75:25 
Accuracy and Kappa both increased a littleâœ¨ bit

### Data Preparation
```{r pre}
# data split
iris1 <- iris
train_index <- createDataPartition(iris1$Species, p = .75, list = FALSE, times = 1)

iris_train <- iris1[train_index,]
iris_test <- iris1[-train_index,]
```

###  Model
```{r model1}
# train
iris_svm_train <- train(
  form = factor(Species) ~.,
  data = iris_train,
  trControl = trainControl(method = "cv",
                           number = 10,
                           classProbs = TRUE),
  method = "svmLinear",
  preProcess = c("center", "scale"),
  tuneLength = 10
)
# iris_svm_train
summary(iris_svm_train)

# predict
iris_svm_predict <- predict(iris_svm_train, iris_test, type = "prob")

iris_svm_predict <- cbind(iris_svm_predict, iris_test)
iris_svm_predict <- iris_svm_predict %>% 
  mutate(prediction = if_else(setosa > versicolor & setosa > virginica, "setosa",
                              if_else(versicolor > setosa & versicolor > virginica, "versicolor",
                                      if_else(virginica > setosa & virginica > versicolor, "virginica", "PROBLEM"))))
# table(iris_svm_predict$prediction)
confusionMatrix(factor(iris_svm_predict$prediction), factor(iris_svm_predict$Species))
```

### Plot SVM
```{r plot}
sv1 <- iris_train[iris_svm_train$finalModel@SVindex,]

ggplot(data = iris_test, mapping = aes(x = Sepal.Width, y= Petal.Width, color = Species)) +
  geom_point(alpha = .5) +
  geom_point(data = iris_svm_predict, mapping = aes(x = Sepal.Width, y = Petal.Width, color = prediction), 
             shape = 6, size = 3) +
  geom_point(data = sv1, mapping = aes(x = Sepal.Width, y = Petal.Width), shape = 4, size = 4) +
  theme(legend.title = element_blank()) +
  ggtitle("Support Vector Machine")
```
